Hi Ken, Faisal,

Following on from your suggestions Ken I was thinking that for
something like moving towards a target it probably makes sense to take
N positions equidistant from the target and also evenly spaced out
around the circumference (spaced every 360/N degrees). In addition you
want to evaluate how the agent responds when oriented differently
relative to the target, so for each of the N positions perform
multiple trials with the agent oriented pointing towards, away from,
at 90 degrees etc.

However, if the agent is egocentric then you don't really need the N
trials spaced around a circumference - they will all amount to
evaulating the same scenario. You may however want to perform trials
using  3 or 4 different (and adjacent) starting poistions if the world
is a grid system because of the subtle sensory differences caused by
aliasing.

If you do start out at a fixed distance then you can assign fitness
based on how close the agent gets to the target within a fixed amount
of time - averaged out for each of the different starting
orientations. Does this seem reasonable?

Colin
